III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention;
Title prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 2/21/24 youth was observed covered with bruises, the right ear
was completely black and blue. On the inside of both elbows there
is a red mark from being restrained by staff who were pulling his
arm. There are scratches on youth’s arms and lower back. The
bruises on youth’s elbows were sustained from youth being
restrained by unknown staff members at the home. It is unknown if
the bruises were sustained from a restraint or from being
physically attacked by other youths.
Investigation This complaint was received on 02/22/2024 and assigned for joint
investigation with MDHHS Specialist.
Interviews:
I contacted complainant on 02/22/2024, no additional information
was provided.
I called and emailed Foster Care Worker on 02/22/2024 and
communication was not returned.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the agency on 02/22/2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 is a youth specialist and has been
working at the facility for one year. Staff 1 denied touching or
physically managing Youth A. He reported on 02/18/2024 Youth A
was mad because he was told he has to eat dinner before he can
have cake, so he left the cottage without permission. Staff 1 tried
to verbally discourage Youth A from leaving the cottage. Staff 1
followed Youth A out of the cottage then drove the agency van,
and followed Youth A. He saw Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth
D, and Youth E around the area by the administration building.
Youth A had a stick and had hit Youth B with it. Youth B in
2

response, tried to hit Youth A. Staff 1 got out of the van and
redirected the youths to stop fighting. Staff 1 said Staff 2 had
redirected the other youths to go back to the cottage. Youth A ran
off towards the main road and the four other youths walked back
to the cottage with Staff 2. Staff 1 followed Youth A with the van
slowly and tried talking to Youth A in attempt to get him to come
back to the cottage. Youth A ran in front of the van into the
wooded area towards six-mile road. Once Staff 1 lost sight of
Youth A, Staff 1 drove to the police department to file a missing
person report. When Staff 1 arrived at the police department, he
was informed Youth A had already been picked up by the police.
The police dropped Youth A off at the campus and Staff 1
completed an incident report. He said Youth A is easily triggered
when he does not get his way and will hit himself. Staff 1 denied
he or any other staff physically managed Youth A. He said the last
time he restrained Youth A was in January. He denied witnessing
any bruises or marks on Youth A that evening.
I interviewed Youth A at the agency on 02/22/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A was observed to
have scratches on his lower arms, a patch of dry skin on his inner
arm, a bruise on his left thigh, and a bruise on his ear. Youth A
said on 02/18/2024 he AWOLed and ran into Youth B, Youth C,
Youth D, and Youth E by the administration building. Youth A
reported he got into a fight with Youth B and Youth C. Youth A
said he hit Youth B with a stick, Youth B and Youth C punched
and kicked Youth A and caused the bruises on his legs and face.
Youth A said Staff 1 told the youth to hit him and Staff 1 tried to
run him over with the van. Youth A was very distracted and
difficult to interview. Youth A said he was restrained but could not
provide a date or time for when this restraint occurred. He then
said he did not want to answer any more questions.
I interviewed Youth B at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth B admitted he got into
a fight with Youth A on 02/18/2024. Youth B said on 02/18/2024,
he, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E were trying to tell Youth A not
to AWOL. Youth A picked up a big stick and hit Youth B, so Youth
B slapped Youth A in the face. Youth B said he was the only one
that Youth A targeted. He does not recall what happened
afterwards because when he’s angry, he has blackouts. Youth B
said he thinks Staff 1 told him to fight Youth A. Youth B denied
witnessing Staff 1 try to run Youth A over with the van.
I interviewed Youth C at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth C recalled the
3

incident involving Youth A and denied hitting or fighting with Youth
A. Youth C said Youth B is the one that hit Youth A. He said Youth
A poked Youth B with a sharp stick and that’s when Youth B
punched and hit Youth A in the face. Youth C denied Staff 1 telling
Youth B to hit Youth A. Youth C said Staff 1 came and told them
to stop fighting and that’s when Youth A ran off into the woods.
I interviewed Youth D at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth D denied hitting or
fighting with Youth A. Youth D said Youth A hit Youth B with a
stick and that’s when Youth B punched and kicked Youth A. Youth
D denied hearing Staff 1 telling Youth B to fight Youth A. Youth D
said Staff 1 came and stopped the fight. Youth D was agitated
during the interview and refused to answer any more questions.
I interviewed Youth E at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth E recalled the
incident and said that Youth A was mad and started hitting him
and the three other youth with a sharp stick. Youth E said Youth B
punched and kicked Youth A. Youth E said Staff 1 came
separated Youth A and Youth B and stop the fight. Youth E said
staff always intervene and stop fights. Youth E denied Staff 1 told
them to fight Youth A and denied witnessing Staff 1 try to run
Youth A over with the van. Youth E did not witness Youth A being
restrained.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 03/05/2024 via telephone, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 recalled the incident on
02/18/2024. Staff 2 said Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E,
ran out of the cottage without permission. She followed the four
youth and went looking for them. While outside looking for the
four youth, she saw Youth A run out of the cottage and Staff 1 and
Supervisor followed Youth A. Staff 1 got in the van and drove
towards the campus exit. Staff 2 started following on foot and
that’s when she saw Staff 1 locate the five youth. She did not
witness the fight but was told by Youth E that Youth A and Youth
B got into a fight. She didn’t witness or hear from the youth that
Staff 1 told the youth to hit Youth A. Staff 2 denied witnessing
Staff 1 restrain Youth A.
I interviewed Supervisor at the agency on 03/05/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Supervisor reported on the
day in question Youth A was triggered because Staff 1 told Youth
A he cannot have cake till after dinner. Youth A ran out of the
cottage and he and Staff 1 followed Youth A outside. Supervisor
said he stayed outside the cottage, and Staff 1 got the van and
4

followed Youth A. Supervisor denied Youth A was restrained or
physically managed by Staff 1.
I interviewed Director at the agency on 03/05/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Director reported Youth A
was not restrained in the month of February.
A predisposition conference held with MDHHS Specialist on
03/21/2024. There is no finding by MDHHS Specialist.
Documents Reviewed:
• Facility Restraint Policy. Crisis Prevention Institute-
Nonviolent Crisis Intervention The staff approach is to apply
nonviolent physical crisis intervention, which is a safe, non-
harmful control and restraint position to safely control a
young person until he can regain control of his behavior.
This is only used as a last resort, after verbal interventions
have been attempted, and the young person presents a
danger to self or others.
• Methodist Intervention Standards and Prohibitions Policy
outlines discipline standards for youth. The agency
prohibits any form of corporal punishment and/or
inappropriate hands-on intervention such as but not limited
to; pinching, spanking, slapping, hitting, twisting arms,
paddling, pulling hair, grabbing, pushing, and threatening
gestures.
• Personnel file for Staff 1 was reviewed and there were no
disciplinary action noted.
• Incident report dated 02/18/2024, noted Youth A was
triggered because he wanted cake for dinner. Youth A left
the cottage without permission and ran towards the
administration building. Staff 1 followed Youth A and drove
the agency van. Staff found Youth A by the administration
building fighting with Youth B, and there were three other
youths nearby. Youth A had a big stick and was hitting
Youth B. Staff 1 got out van and directed Youth A and
Youth B to stop fighting. Youth A ran off and went in the
direction of the woods. Staff 1 went to the Police
Department to file a missing person report and was
informed the police had found Youth A and were
transporting him back to campus.
• Youth A was seen by the Nurse on 02/20/24 for eating a
piece of wood. Youth A had a scratch on his face,
scratches on both arms, a bruise on his right leg, and a
5

scratch on his lower leg. Youth A reported the scratches
were from running in the woods.
• Youth A’s Medical records from Beaumont hospital dated
02/28/2024, confirmed the redness on Youth A’s arms are
dermatitis (Eczema). Youth A was prescribed
hydrocortisone cream.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentations reviewed,
there is insufficient evidence to support the allegations staff
restrained Youth A or caused the bruises and scratches observed
on Youth A. Staff interviewed denied Youth A was restrained.
Youth A was involved in a physical altercation with another Youth,
staff was present, and did intervene. It is believed the bruises
were a result of being involved in a physical altercation with the
other youth. Youth A was examined at Beaumont Hospital on
02/28/2024 and it was confirmed the redness on Youth A’s arms
are dermatitis (Eczema).
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iii)Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 allegedly told other youth to physically harm Youth A.
Investigation I interviewed Staff 1 at the agency on 02/22/2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 denied telling or allowing another
youth to hurt Youth A. Staff 1 said on 02/18/2024 Youth A left the
cottage without permission and got into a physical altercation with
Youth B. Staff 1 followed Youth A and immediately intervened and
separated the two youth.
I interviewed Youth A at the agency on 02/22/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A reported he got into
a fight with Youth B and Youth C. Youth A said he hit Youth B with
a stick, Youth B and Youth C punched and kicked Youth A and
caused the bruises on his legs and face. Youth A said Staff 1 told
the youth to hit him and Staff 1 tried to run him over with the van.
6

I interviewed Youth B at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth B admitted he got into
a fight with Youth A on 02/18/2024. Youth B said on 02/18/2024,
he, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E were trying to tell Youth A not
to AWOL. Youth A picked up a big stick and hit Youth B, so Youth
B slapped Youth A in the face. Youth B said he was the only one
that Youth A targeted. He does not recall what happened
afterwards because when he’s angry, he has blackouts. Youth B
said he thinks Staff 1 told him to fight Youth A. Youth B denied
witnessing Staff 1 try to run Youth A over with the van.
I interviewed Youth C at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth C recalled the
incident involving Youth A and denied hitting or fighting with Youth
A. Youth C said Youth B is the one that hit Youth A. He said Youth
A poked Youth B with a sharp stick and that’s when Youth B
punched and hit Youth A in the face. Youth C denied Staff 1 told
Youth B to hit Youth A and said Staff 1 came to tell them to stop
fighting.
I interviewed Youth D at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth D denied hitting or
fighting with Youth A. Youth D said Youth A hit Youth B with a
stick and that’s when Youth B punched and kicked Youth A. Youth
D denied hearing Staff 1 telling Youth B to fight Youth A. Youth D
said Staff 1 came and stopped the fight. Youth A was agitated
during the interview and refused to answer any more questions.
I interviewed Youth E at the agency on 02/27/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth D recalled the
incident and said that Youth A was mad and started hitting him
and the three other youth with a sharp stick. Youth D said Youth B
punched and kicked Youth A. Youth E said Staff 1 came and
separated Youth A and Youth B and stopped the fight. Youth E
said staff always intervene and stop fights. Youth E denied Staff 1
tried to run Youth A over with the van and denied hearing Staff 1
telling Youth B to fight Youth A.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 03/05/2024 via telephone, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 did not witness the fight but was
told by Youth E that Youth A and Youth B got into a fight. She
didn’t witness or hear from the youth that Staff 1 told the youth to
hit Youth A.
7

Analysis Based on interviews conducted, there is insufficient evidence to
support the allegations staff told another youth to hit Youth A.
Youth A was involved in a fight with another youth, staff
intervened and stopped the fight.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff were unaware Youth A AWOLed until police contacted them.
Investigation I interviewed Staff 1 at the agency on 02/22/2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 reported on 02/20/2024, Youth A
left the cottage without permission, and Staff 1 immediately
followed Youth A outside then drove the agency van to follow
Youth A and attempted to get Youth A to come back to the
cottage. When he lost sight of Youth A, Staff 1 went to the police
department to file a report.
I interviewed Youth A at the agency on 02/22/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A reported he
AWOLed on 02/20/2024, Staff 1 followed him and tried to get him
to go back to the cottage. Youth A said the police picked him up
and drove him back to campus.
I interviewed Supervisor at the agency on 03/05/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Supervisor reported Youth A
AWOLed on 02/18/2024 and he and Staff 1 followed Youth A
immediately. He said Staff 1 drove the van and followed Youth A.
Supervisor said the agency policy is to follow the youth and make
all efforts to maintain line of sight. Staff 1 followed Youth A as far
as possible and when he lost line sight, Staff 1 went to the police
station to file a missing person report. Supervisor is not aware of
any AWOL incidents that were not reported to the police
department.
8

I interviewed Director on 03/05/2024 at the agency. Director
reported the agency has several youths that AWOL frequently and
the staff are expected to make all efforts to maintain eyesight of
the youth. If youths leave the grounds, staff follow them as far as
possible without endangering the youth's safety. If staff lose
eyesight of them, the police are contacted, and a missing person’s
report is filed. Director said all staff follow the agency policy to
ensure the safety of the youth when they leave the campus
without permission.
I interviewed Detective with Redford Police Department via
telephone on 03/06/2024. Detective reported he does not have
concerns regarding the agency not reporting AWOLs.
Documents Reviewed:
• Facility’s AWOL policy. Staff are expected to make all
efforts to maintain eyesight of the youth(s). If youths leave
the grounds, staff should get a van and follow them. If
youths AWOL but stay on campus and go into the woods,
staff should contact the supervisor, follow calmly on foot,
and verbally attempt to return them. Staff must follow
youths as far as possible without endangering their own
safety. If youths retreat further into the woods and staff lose
eyesight of them, the police should be contacted, and a
missing persons reports filed.
Analysis The facility is compliant with the rule, Staff were supervising Youth
A prior to him going AWOL and followed the agency’s AWOL
policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
